raw_text:
China 'to overtake US net use'
 
 The Chinese net-using population looks set to exceed that of the US in less than three years, says a report.
 
 China's net users number 100m but this represents less than 8% of the country's 1.3 billion people. Market analysts Panlogic predicts that net users in China will exceed the 137 million US users of the net by 2008. The report says that the country's culture will mean that Chinese people will use the net for very different ends than in many other nations.
 
 Already net use in China has a very different character than in many Western nations, said William Makower, chief executive of Panlogic. In many Western nations desktop computers that can access the net are hard to escape at work. By contrast in China workplace machines are relatively rare. This, combined with the relatively high cost of PCs in China and the time it takes to get phone lines installed, helps to explains the huge number of net cafes in China. Only 36% of Chinese homes have telephones according to reports. "Net usage tends to happen in the evening," said Mr Makower, "they get access only when they go home and go off to the internet café." "Its fundamentally different usage to what we have here," he said.
 
 Net use in China was still very much an urban phenomenon with most users living on the country's eastern seaboard or in its three biggest cities. The net is key to helping Chinese people keep in touch with friends, said Mr Makower. Many people use it in preference to the phone or arrange to meet up with friends at net cafes. What people can do on the net is also limited by aspects of Chinese life. For instance, said Mr Makower, credit cards are rare in China partly because of fears people have about getting in to debt. "The most popular way to pay is Cash-On-Delivery," he said, "and that's quite a brake to the development of e-commerce." The arrival of foreign banks in China, due in 2006, could mean greater use of credit cards but for the moment they are rare, said Mr Makower. But if Chinese people are not spending cash online they are interested in the news they can get via the net and the view it gives them on Western ways of living. "A large part of the attraction of the internet is that it goes below the radar," he said. "Generally it's more difficult for the government to be able to control it." "Its real value is as an open window onto what's happening elsewhere in the world," he said. Government restrictions on how much advertising can appear on television means that the net is a source of many commercial messages Chinese people would not see anywhere else. Familiarity with the net also has a certain social cachet. "It's a sign of them having made it that they can use the internet and navigate around it," said Mr Makower.
llama3.2:1b: China's population of 1.3 billion is expected to surpass that of the US in fewer than three years, according to market analysts.
China has 100 million net users but only about 8% of its population uses the internet.
The country's unique culture and limited access to PCs at work contribute to its high rate of internet use, with many people using it primarily for socializing and staying connected with friends.
llama3.2:3b: China's net users are expected to surpass US users in less than three years, growing from 100 million to over 137 million by 2008.

China's net usage is distinct due to its urban focus, limited credit card adoption, and cultural differences, with many using the internet for communication and accessing global news rather than e-commerce.
gemma2:2b: China's internet population is expected to surpass the US population by 2008, according to market analysts.
Chinese net usage differs significantly from Western nations due to factors such as low PC penetration, limited workplace access, and reliance on net cafes.
The internet serves primarily for social networking and communication, with a preference for cash-on-delivery payments and limited e-commerce activity due to a lack of credit cards.
However, the Chinese internet offers an alternative source of information regarding global events and provides a window into Western culture, making it valuable for understanding other societies.
qwen2.5:0.5b: The report predicts China will surpass the US in net usage within three years, with Chinese culture influencing how users interact with the internet compared to Western nations where desktop computers are more common.
The report notes that workplace machines are not as common due to limited telecommunication options and high costs of computers.
The majority of users use the internet at home and work, particularly during evenings.
Internet cafes in China tend to be few, and users access their computers on their way out.
While credit cards are used for online payments, this is a significant barrier for many Chinese people.
Chinese people generally use the internet as a source of news, and it offers them insights into Western ways of life.
The value of the internet lies in its ability to open up opportunities outside traditional media.
qwen2.5:1.5b: China will surpass America in net users by 2008, according to Panlogic, citing urbanization, high cost, limited PC access, and cultural differences as reasons for China's significantly different net usage habits compared to Western nations.
qwen2.5:3b: China's net-using population is expected to surpass that of the US in less than three years, according to a report.
With 100 million users representing just 8% of China’s population, analysts predict this number will reach over 137 million by 2008 when compared to the US’s 137 million net users.
Chinese internet usage differs significantly from Western countries due to factors like rare workplace computers and high PC costs; it is predominantly used in evening hours at internet cafes.
The report notes that China's internet use is primarily urban, with many people using it for social interactions or keeping up with news about foreign cultures.
Limited credit card availability restricts e-commerce development but has also created interest in international news and ways of life.
opencoder:1.5b:
China, 'to overtake US net use' 

The Chinese net-using population looks set to exceed that of the US in less than three years, reports a market analyst Panlogic.
The country's net users number 100m but this represents less than 8% of the country's 1.3 billion people.
Market analysts say that net users in China will exceed the 137 million US users by 2008, a huge difference compared to many other nations.
The report also highlights that the country's culture means that Chinese people will use the net for very different ends than in many other countries.
China has already shown a very different character compared to Western nations in terms of desktop computers and workplace machines.
This is reflected by the increased number of net cafes, where Chinese people can stay until they get home and go off at these places.
The difference in technology, price, and time taken to install phone lines are among the reasons behind this.
In comparison with US net users, China's net usage is still quite urban and popular, where most users live on the eastern seaboard or in its three biggest cities.
This suggests a different way of communication compared to Western countries.
The rise of foreign banks could mean greater use of credit cards but as of now, they are rare due to fears about getting in to debt.
The net usage can also be seen as an open window into the world's current and future happenings.
It may offer new opportunities for Chinese people to stay connected with friends or for them to get news that they would not have found otherwise.
Despite government restrictions on how much advertising can appear on TV, it provides a source of commercial messages for Chinese people who wouldn't see anything else in the world.
Moreover, while the net is popular among many other nations, its lack of universal access may be due to fears about overpaying bills or maintaining credit status.
The rise of smartphones could make mobile internet a more attractive option for these users compared to desktop internet.
As it is known, smartphones can be accessed when they are at work and on the go, hence providing greater versatility in terms of communication.
smollm:1.7b: The Chinese net-using population looks set to overtake that of the US in less than three years, says a report.
The report cites market analysts Panlogic as predicting that China's net users will exceed those of the US by 2008.

This is likely due to several factors:

1.
**Cultural differences**: Net usage tends to happen in the evening, and this is more common in Western cultures where people have access to computers at home.
In contrast, many Chinese people prefer to use their PCs during the day when they are at work or school.
**High cost of PCs**: Only 36% of Chinese homes have telephones, which means that most people do not have access to the internet at home.
This makes it more difficult for them to get online and use the net.
In contrast, many Western countries have a high percentage of households with computers and internet access is widely available.
**Limited availability**: The net is not as ubiquitous in China as it is in other parts of the world.
Many Chinese people do not have access to the internet at home or are limited by their geographical location.
This means that they may be more likely to use the net at work, where computers and internet access are readily available.
**Alternative ways of communication**: In China, there is a strong culture of face-to-face communication and phone calls are often preferred over email or instant messaging.
The net has not yet replaced these traditional forms of communication in China.
**Government restrictions**: The Chinese government has been more restrictive about the use of the internet than many other governments.
This means that there is less freedom for people to access the net and use it as they see fit.
In contrast, many Western countries have a relatively open internet policy.

**Foreign banks in China**: Foreign banks are not widely available in China, which limits the options for Chinese people who want to use the net to make international transactions or access financial services.
**Credit card usage**: Credit cards are rare in China partly because of fears about getting in to debt.
Many Chinese people prefer to pay cash online and this is a more difficult way to make purchases online.
**Foreign news sources**: The internet has made it easier for Chinese people to access foreign news sources, which can be a significant factor in shaping their opinions on global issues.
However, there are also restrictions on the types of content that can be published online in China.
**Government control**: The Chinese government has been more restrictive about the use of the net than many other governments.
This means that there is less freedom for people to access the net and use it as they see fit.
In contrast, many Western countries have a relatively open internet policy.
**Alternative ways of accessing information**: There are alternative ways of accessing information in China, such as through traditional media like newspapers or television.
This can make it more difficult for Chinese people to access the same range of information that is available online.
deepseek-r1:1.5b: China’s net-use population is projected to exceed US net-use by 2008, with China’s net users at 100 million (under 8% of the country’s 13 billion people), exceeding US’ 137 million users.
The cultural difference lies in work machines versus phone use, with Chinese cafes dominating net-access activities due to rare telephone access and high PC costs.
Credit card usage is discouraged by fears of debt, and foreign banks may open accounts affecting e-commerce growth.
The net’s appeal includes global insights and attracting information on Western living styles.
Government restrictions on advertising and the net’s cachet make it a unique tool for commercial communication.
tinyllama:1.1b: A report estimates that China's net-using population, which includes only 100 million people, will surpass that of the US by 2008.

The key difference between Chinese and Western cultures is the way users access the internet - in cities and towns only PCs are available, while the number of net cafes exceeds those in many Western nations.
Net use in China is fundamental to helping people stay in touch with friends, and the country's e-commerce potential could be a draw for foreign banks due in 2006.
The net attracts general attention but has a social cache among Chinese citizens who can navigate it themselves or rely on cash-on-deliveries.
Government restrictions on advertising are important sources of commercial messages in China.
tinydolphin:1.1b: China will overtake the US in terms of net users by 2008, according to a report from Panlogic.
China's net-users number 100 million, but this represents only 8% of the country's population.
Market analyst William Makower predicts that net users in China will exceed those in the US by 2008.
The report explains that Chinese people use the internet for very different ends than in many Western nations.
By contrast, workplace machines are relatively rare and access to them is challenging for many Chinese individuals.
This, combined with the relatively high cost of PCs in China and the time it takes to get phone lines installed, helps explain why there are so many net cafes in China compared to Western countries.
phi:2.7b: The Chinese are predicted to have more net users than the US in less than three years, according to a report.
While China has 100 million net users, only 8% of its 1.3 billion population uses the net.
However, this number is expected to exceed 137 million US internet users by 2008.
Chinese people use the net for different purposes from Western nations and tend to go online in the evenings after work.
Net cafes are popular in China because workplaces have fewer computers than in the West, phones are relatively expensive, and it can take time to get phone lines installed.
Net use is mostly an urban phenomenon with most users living on China's eastern seaboard or in its three biggest cities.
Credit cards are rare in China due to fears about getting into debt.
The internet gives Chinese people access to Western news and ways of life.
The government has difficulty controlling the internet, which allows for open communication and diverse opinions.
orca-mini:3b: China is expected to surpass the United States in terms of its net users within three years, according to a report by Panlogic.
This is due to the relatively low cost of computers and phone lines in China, as well as the high percentage of homes without phones.
Net cafes are popular in China, where people often use the internet for socializing with friends or searching for news and information.
The Chinese government limits its control over the internet by allowing advertising to appear on certain websites.
However, the net has a different culture in China compared to other Western countries, and is used primarily for socializing.
hermes3:3b: China to surpass US in net users within 3 years, according to report.
Chinese net users will outnumber US users by 2008.

Key differences in net usage between China and Western nations:
- Different character due to workplace machines being rare.
- Net use is an urban phenomenon primarily on the east coast or in major cities.
- Limited by aspects like fear of debt and Cash-On-Delivery payment method for online shopping.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: China is predicted to overtake the US in terms of internet users within less than three years, with market analysts Panlogic estimating that 100 million Chinese net users will exceed 137 million US users by 2008.
This is due in part to cultural differences, with Chinese people using the internet for different purposes compared to Western nations.
In China, workplace computers are relatively rare, and many homes do not have telephones, leading to a high number of internet cafes and limited access during evenings when people return home.
The popularity of Cash-On-Delivery as a form of payment also poses a challenge for e-commerce development in the country.

While government restrictions on advertising on television mean that the internet is a source of many commercial messages not seen elsewhere, familiarity with the net has become a sign of social status and success in China.
stablelm2:1.6b: China's net user population is set to surpass that of the US within less than three years, according to a report by Panlogic.
Chinese net users number about 500 million out of a total of 1.3 billion people, with only 8% belonging to households with telephones.
Net cafes are prevalent in China due to the limited access to computers and phones at home.
Urban areas are where most users reside, while rural areas have fewer internet users.
The internet is essential for Chinese people to keep in touch with friends and share information on social media.
Credit cards are rare in China because of financial concerns about debt, particularly with Cash-On-Delivery as the primary payment method.
A growing interest in e-commerce from foreign banks could potentially change this trend.

At present, news and views accessed through the internet give Chinese people a broader view of Western ways of life, and the internet remains a source of many commercial messages that are not regulated by local governments.
The use of credit cards is rare, but an increasing number of Chinese people are using the internet to keep in touch with friends and access information on social media.
granite3.1-dense:2b: China's internet user base, currently at 100 million (less than 8% of its population), is projected to surpass the US' net users (137 million) by 2008, according to Panlogic.
This disparity arises from distinct cultural factors and economic realities.

In contrast to Western nations where desktop computers are prevalent in workplaces, China's internet usage is primarily confined to net cafes due to limited PC access, high PC costs, and slow telephone line installation.
Only 36% of Chinese homes have landlines.
Net use in China is predominantly urban, with users residing along the eastern seaboard or in major cities like Beijing and Shanghai.
The internet serves as a crucial tool for maintaining connections with friends, often supplanting phone calls and facilitating meetups at net cafes.
Chinese online activities are constrained by aspects of Chinese life.
For instance, cash-on-delivery is the most common form of payment due to debt concerns, hindering e-commerce growth.
Credit cards, rare in China, could increase post-2006 with foreign bank entry.

Meanwhile, news and international perspectives drive internet usage, offering an "open window" into global affairs, which is otherwise restricted by government advertisement regulations on television.
Lastly, internet proficiency signifies social status in China, indicating one's capability to navigate the digital world and access information beyond traditional channels.
chatgpt-4o-latest: China's internet user base, currently at 100 million, is expected to surpass the U.S.'s 137 million users by 2008, despite only 8% of China's 1.3 billion population being online.
Internet usage in China differs significantly from Western nations due to limited workplace access, high PC costs, and low telephone penetration, leading to widespread use of internet cafes.
Usage is primarily urban, concentrated in major cities, and serves as a key communication tool.
E-commerce growth is hindered by the rarity of credit cards, though foreign banks' entry in 2006 may change this.
The internet provides Chinese users with access to global news and culture, bypassing government controls, and carries social prestige as a sign of modernity.
